page.title: 07Enfield Palace
page.content: Enfield Palace was built for Elizabeth I by her brother Edward. Pearson's store now stands in the place of the Palace. The restaurant has been named after the Cedar tree in the grounds of the Palace. It became famous because it grew to a massive height. It was planted by Sir Robert Uvedale who was a famous botanist and also master of the Enfield Grammar School for many years. The tree survived until this century, when it was pulled down to make way for a shopping precinct, which stands today. There is no evidence that Elizabeth lived in the Palace after she was crowned Queen, but she did before. When it was destroyed the oak panelling, fireplace & two decorated ceilings were sold & erected in a house in Gentleman's Row. In its time the Palace was used as a private school & a post office.
